reviewText:
OverviewHook is a very short, mechanical puzzle game. Expect about an hour of thinking in this lovely little project with a minimalist approach.

The Pros:Great Design - If you've played this king of games, you won't feel anything new. It follows the philosophy of less is more, and for a game that was built around a prototype, it's a great choice. You'll find a simple color scheme, almost no UI, and a generic backing music.

Interesting Gameplay - You have to remap circuit like structures by rotating nodes to guide the signal of your buttons. The goal is to retract the variously shaped bars without them colliding. Think of it as the electrician's lockpicking game.

Self Cleaning Levels - I love it how when you clear part of a level, the now useless wiring and nodes disappear on their own. It makes following wires easier and lets you concentrate on the remaining part of the puzzle.

Dirt Cheap - Honestly, you can't ask for more money on a game that is so short, but damn it, for the one hour of pleasant wiring I've done, I'm glad I bough this dev a coffee.

Achievements - Achievement hunters, rejoice! A single achievement is required, and that is completing the game!
The Cons:Short - The game mechanics are awesome, I loved the idea, and I am sad there are only 50 levels of content, which will take you roughly an hour to complete. Custom levels would have been amazing to see here, but sadly, it is not the case.

No Menus - The game is short enough that you will probably just pass through it in one sitting then you will leave it dusting on the hypothetical shelf until you are bored, so I understand why he didn't bother to include menus, but I still have to deduct points for no options whatsoever. Especially that you have to go through levels one by one. That is to say, if you enjoyed level 35, prepare to increment your way to it!
ConclusionThe game is fun, interesting, and literally costs a cup of coffee. You have nothing to lose, grab it!

reviewText:
What is Hook?

Hook is a minimalistic and short puzzle game where you must hook in hooks. Sounds easy, is it for the most part.

Idea: The idea itself is nice but simple, there might be some unused potential, but overall the concept makes only for an easy, zen-like game. You solve the puzzles because you want to solve them, they are no real brain teasers but rather resolving challenges, such as opening a knot. You have a series of interconnected hooks and lines to them. Your objective is to reel them in in the correct order so no hook touches another one. Later stages give you three tries for each puzzle before it resets. You should not need any of the additional tries anyway. Earlier stages have unlimited tries.

Graphics: The graphics are held entirely in black, grey and white. While I have per se no issues with the graphics, there is one thing that is annoying. More than once I tried to unhook something that I thought to be the next hook but it still was interconnected somehow, so I solved the wrong one. Maybe it is because I get near my thirties, or because I always had some bad eyesight, but to me sometimes it is difficult to see what hooks are connected to what. The solution might have been to color the hooks, although that should be an option and not enforced as it would destroy some graphical charme.

Sound: The sound is minimalistic as well, with no artistic value. It is all made to be calm.

Controls: The control is done with the mouse. As they are completely intuitive, you spend more time thinking than clicking.


Recommended: Yes, but for one dollar or less. There is a free version on Kongregate which can be viewed as a demo, as the author also states on the store page. The game is calming while still managing to be something to think on, but not too much, just the right amount to relax, which is appreciated.

The game has 50 levels and they are generally short since the concept itself is not allowing for much difficulty. I finished it in just under an hour.


Verdict: Calming puzzle game in the Zen philosophy. (The philosophy of Zen is to live in the current moment, neither thinking of the future nor the past.)

Short, but sweet!

Earlier today someone on my friends list had played and reviewed this game, it sounded interesting so I thought I would have a look. It’s safe to say that I’m glad I did.

This game is simple, short but satisfying. With 50 levels, it took me around 65 minutes to complete. It definitely won’t keep you busy for long but the time it does, I think you will enjoy it.

I love puzzle games with more unique mechanics. Games like Splice, KAMI and LYNE are always the type of thing I am looking out for. Hook is nice little addition to the group. The mechanics are simple to pick up and get increasingly harder as you go along whilst still being fun to work through.

Despite the praise above even the hardest levels didn’t feel too much of a head scratcher. If you are looking for a more casual puzzle game to play, this may be it. But if you’re looking for a hard-core challenge well you might be disappointed.

Either way this game is great. The music is very chill, the graphics are decent and it was all around a good buy. I paid about 70p for it, so no complaints here!

This game only has 1 achievement and that’s for completing all the levels. So in terms of getting another perfected game, this one couldn’t be easier.

All in all it’s a nice little game, I’d definitely recommend it.

reviewText:
This is a really hard game to review. I was torn on whether to say Yea or Nay to it. Ultimately, I decided to not recommend it—even if it is pretty neat.

Puzzle games are my thing, for sure. Simplistic and minimal? That counts for double. For what this game is, the vibe is absolutely perfect, starting right from the title screen/first level. I have to give props to the game trailer, too. Leaving it to the player to discover what the game is about is very compelling.

However, sometimes you have things are too simplistic and too minimal. I'm afraid Hook falls into this category. I completed all 50 levels of the game in 50 minutes. That's all there is. There is nothing for me to go back to. (I wish there was.)

Things don't get satisfactorily difficult until the last 10 levels. To me, the first 30ish levels felt like an expanded tutorial. They built up new concepts nicely, but in the end there are very few levels where you are really challenged on them. In fact, there is one mechanic that is introduced then abandoned after just 2 levels, never to be seen again. Why put it in if you don't have a real test for it later in the game?

I read the reviews for this game beforehandand I knew that I was going to get what amounts to a disposable, one-time use product. You buy it, you use it, you're done with it. I'm satisfied with what I got, but that doesn't mean I'd recommend it to everyone.

Hook is a neat game, but it's not a good value. There are many other games, on Steam or on smartphones, that also cost less than a dollar, but they will have much more content and are probably worth your time more than this one is worth your money.

reviewText:
I beat this game in an hour, but I was still impressed enough to leave a comment.

Before I bought the game, I had no idea what was going on in the trailer video, but the mechanics are not difficult to understand. The object of the game is to retract all of the hooks on the screen. You do this by pressing the buttons, and any hooks connected by wires to the buttons will attempt to retract. You need to do this in the correct order, because if any hooks collide and fail to retract, the whole board resets and you have to start over. Later in the game, there will be many hooks connected to one button, and you will be required to manipulate gates to cut the connections to the hooks which shouldn't retract yet.

The game only has 50 levels. The first 39 levels are practically a tutorial to make sure you understand the mechanics. The real challenge starts with the final 11 levels, which are quite complex, and give you three failing attempts before the board resets instead of just one.

For a $0.99 game, I was very satisfied. I would recommend it to any puzzle game fans and achievement hunters who would enjoy a momentary lapse into something original, yet simple.

reviewText:
Hook is a very, very relaxing puzzle game. Minimalist in its design, with only a white background and black lines and buttons for presentation, you’re thrown straight into the puzzle without so much as a tutorial. And that’s okay, you don’t really need a tutorial. Every time a new item is added to the puzzles,  you’re given a very simple version to solve that teaches you what the new symbols do. The basic idea is that you will remove the items in order, taking care none will hook or get stuck with another.

When I say the game is minimalist, I do mean it’s minimalist: it doesn’t even have a menu. Normally I’d be pretty annoyed without control over the sound, but in this case, I didn’t need it. Hook’s sound effects and backgrounds music/sound are soft, pleasant, and as relaxing as the rest of the game is.

The puzzles themselves aren’t difficult, in fact, the game is quite easy and short with only 50 levels, and only the last few levels are more complicated (because of all the ramifications, and not because they’re actually hard) The game even offers you 3 tries on those latter levels, so that you won’t lose at the first mistake.

The only complaint I had was the windowed mode. Alt+enter did take you out of fullscreen and into window mode, but at the same resolution. I made the mistake of resizing the window on the hopes it would help the resolution aspect, but it only cut off part of my puzzle area; alt+entering back to full screen did not reset this, nor did resizing the window again, so I was forever left with a thin black line at the top and bottom of my game screen that cut off a tiny bit of the puzzles.
Still, it wasn’t game breaking as I didn’t resize it too small (thankfully).

If you like these kind of puzzle games (and even though you might not find a huge challenge in this), if you need something relaxing to play then I definitely recommend it. It’s worth the money.

reviewText:
One-dollar games are notoriously difficult to review.  Generally, they deliberately offer such a short experience so that you really cannot judge how good the game is by its length. You really can't expect much for a buck.

So what it ultimately boils down to is whether that short experience is worth not only your one euro, one dollar, slightly less than one pound or whatever, but also whether it's worth your time. What you're essentially getting here is one hour's worth of gameplay for your money - maybe a little more if you struggle with logic puzzles.

The problem with Hook is that the game never really takes off into greatness. You spend the first 25-30 levels asking yourself if this is all that the game has to offer, after which the game starts to up the difficulty slightly, giving you hope that you may eventually be challenged.

Many puzzle fans, sadly, will be disappointed. Hook blows its contingent of new features by the mid-way point and never introduces anything new thereafter except slightly increased complexity in the layouts. And ironically, it's a hook that Hook is missing - you don't get much of an a-ha" feeling when you solve a puzzle - each one is solved by simple patience and superficial logic
date: the kind that electronic engineers will doubtless be familiar with from reading circuit diagrams.\n\nHook certainly won't give you the feeling of having wasted your dosh - especially so if you buy it in a sale or bundle. Its contemporary miminalist visual and audio style is serviceable and functional but by no means revolutionary. But it will have you wondering if it was an hour well-spent. TL;DR: Minimalistic and nice but short, casual puzzle game about untangling hooks.

Rarely does a puzzle game start so leisurely. The first couple of levels of Hook are impossible to fail, their sole purpose being to demonstrate core mechanics. After all, a single hook cannot be tangled with itself.

In Hook bunch of abstract hooks are piled in an elaborate manner to present a puzzle. Your mission is to pick out all hooks one or few at a time without them getting stuck to each other in the process. Pressing a button, connected to a hook by a line, activates the hook to be removed. If it's not obstructed, you are one step closer to success.

Hook is well designed. Success is usually not too difficult but it still feels satisfying as you solve a puzzle. All new features are introduced naturally by incredible simple and easy puzzles instead of bulky tutorials or manuals.

A couple of special features spice up the puzzles: there are rotating switches that control which hooks get activated; plus there are antennae" that transfer the "hook activation signal" like teleporters. These add up to increasingly complicated puzzles.

reviewText:
Hook  is an elegant little puzzle game that's nice to play in a meditative, mind clearing sort of way. The precepts of how the pieces interact are intuitive and the puzzles themselves are skillfully designed, with my only frustration arising from taking longer than was intended to figure out how overlapping pathways do and do not interact. The sound design and music fit well within the overall aesthetic.

This game does not present real challenge or require creativity. Even the most complex looking levels are fairly simple to sort out by a mental process that ends up mainly being the process of elimination and following lines, and there is generally only one way to solve each puzzle. I recommend this game for someone who enjoys the simple satisfaction of carefully putting things in place for an experience rather like a jigsaw puzzle. There's nothing here that you will force you to return repeatedly or develop a novel solution.

I doubt using the same puzzle building blocks would allow for the addition of new and deeply challenging problems. In any case I would rather see more of the same: simple satisfying puzzles that can help you clear your mind.

All in all, worth your dollar.

A Paladin’s Steam Review: Hook. It’s Short, Cheap, Minimalist Fun. Genre: Minimalist Puzzle Game
Developed & Published by: Maciej Targoni, Wojciech Wasiak and Rainbow Train.
Platform: Windows, Mac, Linux.
Business Model: Single Purchase
Copy Purchased by Myself Overall Gameplay Thoughts
Hook is a short minimalist puzzle game. It’s so minimalist that there isn’t even a main menu. The game just throws you right into the first simple puzzle to explain it’s main mechanic. This is a game about figuring out which order to push all of the buttons on the screen. Each button is tied to a hook(s) or line(s) that must be retracted in the right order. What it then does is explore how far it can push that mechanic through a mess of lines that have to be traced through to make sure you don’t activate any other hooks that you don’t want to. Eventually, there are switches that change which lines are affected by a button press that you have to work around. You only get one chance to fail each puzzle up until halfway through where the game gives you three chances to fail. In total there are 50 puzzles that you can do in about an hour. Which seems to be a decent length considering what the developer was working with. I’d say my only criticism of the pacing is that the puzzles don’t get really challenging until the 30th one, for myself anyway.

PC Settings
There aren’t any PC settings in Hook. At all. The game seems to auto-detect what the resolution is. It runs at 60FPS. That’s all there is to say. It works on Linux just fine. I’m willing to forgive it considering it’s short length but yeah, there’s nothing to talk about here.

Final Thoughts
Yeah, so that’s my thoughts on Hook. There’s not a lot to examine or talk about in Hook. It’s a well done minimalist puzzle game that costs $0.99 and doesn’t pretend to be anything else. Kudos to the devs for being straightforward on the marketing. So, if you need another one of these, give Hook a look. An hour of casual entertainment for 99 cents, not a bad deal. Recommended.

reviewText:
First, this game has a nice visual style and good ambient sound. Having it onscreen was pleasant. That's largely why I aquired it.

But I didn't particularly enjoy playing the puzzles. Many of the levels, perhaps half, weren't difficult at all. Then the game seems to try and generate difficulty through complexity, meaning that the main reason you'd fail at a puzzle is not that you don't know what you need to do, but that you simply have trouble telling what is conected to what in the jumble of black lines on-screen. This makes the game more about repeatedly tracing lines than about figuring things out. A few levels did involve some sort of insight, but only a few, and always insight of the same sort.

Also, the game is very short. I beat it in what Steam tells me is 64 minutes of play time, and I was AFK for at least 10 of those, probably more. (So that's < 54 minutes from start to finish without any prior familiarity with the game.)

All that is not to say it's an aweful game. This might be some people's cup of tea, and the price is right. But for minimal puzzlers I'd rather play something else.

The game teaches you how to play through the earlier few levels as the game gets progressively harder. More and more 'elements' are added to the puzzle and combined with eariler ones to form more complex puzzles. I did find it to be a little easy, ~40 minutes to beat all 50 levels, but I feel the concept is sound and many more puzzles and elements could be added in the future. Good ambient sound track, clean visuals, easy mechanics, learn-as-you-play, but a little too-easy once you get the hang of figuring them out. Overall I would give it a 8/10.

It would be nice to have some sort of scoring mechanism, fewest clicks/turn of elements or something along that line to increase the replayablity of it.

reviewText:
The obligatory pun first: It got me hooked. (I am sorry)

Hook is a clever short puzzle game with 50 levels. The objective of each level is to essentially reel in every single hook on screen, which gets increasingly difficult as the levels progress, introducing things like teleporters, switches and so on.

I played through the game in one hour and it was great fun! The puzzles started out easy and eventually grew very challenging but always remained solvable, the sounds are minimalistic yet serve the game perfectly (just like the graphics) and I certainly got my money's worth. If you enjoy fair puzzle games and look for an hour of simple fun, look no further than here - it is easily worth the money. I can see no drawbacks or bad things about this game; the short length is perfect to keep it fun, anything longer than that would quickly let it grow stale.

Simply said, a perfect short puzzler.

reviewText:
'Hook' has quite a smart and simple concept to be a puzzle game, but it lacks content and it can not be seen as a fully-fledged game (sorry to say that)!

Desc:
You solve a puzzle by freeing all sticked together gates. You're activating electricity through clicking on a power supply button. The electricity will flow through the wire to its gate/object/goal. The object which is connected to the wire will slide backwards and disappear. This will free other objects which now can be connected to free others and so on. There are a hand full of object types you can interact with: a simple line, a curve, a Y junction and three types of wireless transponder to solve the puzzles.

Pros:
+ charming concept
+ artwork fits
+ smooth soundtrack
+ smooth rise of difficulty

Cons:
- not difficult at all
- only 50 level
- with 1h a really short play time
- too expensive for this play time (and i brought it on sale for 0,99€)
(- missing animation to see where the electricity flows)
(- missing option to control the animation speed)
(- missing other control objects)
(- missing a better level navigator to jump directly to a level)

Suggestions:
~ the game would be much cooler with more levels, with more upcoming freaky puzzles and with more difficulty
~ another improvement would be an animation where you see the electricity flowing and a button to control the animation speed
~ the last idea would be to create more control objects
: forming object, where electricity changes its color or form
: infrared objects, where electricity will be ported from one place to another but only vertical or horizontal
: timing objects, where the divided electricity needs to be timed to get to its gate
: etc

As you can see there is a lot of potential, but it's currently not really used to be a fully-fledged game.

Not Recommended, even if it's on sale, because it lacks content really hard.

4/10

What is Hook?

Hook is a minimalistic and short puzzle game where you must hook in hooks. Sounds easy, is it for the most part.

Idea: The idea itself is nice but simple, there might be some unused potential, but overall the concept makes only for an easy, zen-like game. You solve the puzzles because you want to solve them, they are no real brain teasers but rather resolving challenges, such as opening a knot. You have a series of interconnected hooks and lines to them. Your objective is to reel them in in the correct order so no hook touches another one. Later stages give you three tries for each puzzle before it resets. You should not need any of the additional tries anyway. Earlier stages have unlimited tries.

Graphics: The graphics are held entirely in black, grey and white. While I have per se no issues with the graphics, there is one thing that is annoying. More than once I tried to unhook something that I thought to be the next hook but it still was interconnected somehow, so I solved the wrong one. Maybe it is because I get near my thirties, or because I always had some bad eyesight, but to me sometimes it is difficult to see what hooks are connected to what. The solution might have been to color the hooks, although that should be an option and not enforced as it would destroy some graphical charme.

Sound: The sound is minimalistic as well, with no artistic value. It is all made to be calm.

Controls: The control is done with the mouse. As they are completely intuitive, you spend more time thinking than clicking.


Recommended: Yes, but for one dollar or less. There is a free version on Kongregate which can be viewed as a demo, as the author also states on the store page. The game is calming while still managing to be something to think on, but not too much, just the right amount to relax, which is appreciated.

The game has 50 levels and they are generally short since the concept itself is not allowing for much difficulty. I finished it in just under an hour.

Hook is a minimalistic and short puzzle game where you must hook in hooks. Sounds easy, is it for the most part.

Idea: The idea itself is nice but simple, there might be some unused potential, but overall the concept makes only for an easy, zen-like game. You solve the puzzles because you want to solve them, they are no real brain teasers but rather resolving challenges, such as opening a knot. You have a series of interconnected hooks and lines to them. Your objective is to reel them in in the correct order so no hook touches another one. Later stages give you three tries for each puzzle before it resets. You should not need any of the additional tries anyway. Earlier stages have unlimited tries.

Graphics: The graphics are held entirely in black, grey and white. While I have per se no issues with the graphics, there is one thing that is annoying. More than once I tried to unhook something that I thought to be the next hook but it still was interconnected somehow, so I solved the wrong one. Maybe it is because I get near my thirties, or because I always had some bad eyesight, but to me sometimes it is difficult to see what hooks are connected to what. The solution might have been to color the hooks, although that should be an option and not enforced as it would destroy some graphical charme.

Sound: The sound is minimalistic as well, with no artistic value. It is all made to be calm.

Recommended: Yes, but for one dollar or less. There is a free version on Kongregate which can be viewed as a demo, as the author also states on the store page. I don’t consider myself a particularly smart person. Which is obviously why I greatly enjoy puzzle games, because they fill me with a sense of intelligence after overcoming certain particularly difficult puzzles. It sort of gives me the feeling that I’m smarter than whoever came up with these challenges in the first place. And I know that this is a very inaccurate representation of people who make puzzle games, because I realize that coming up with these difficult brainteasers in the first place requires an intellect far greater than mine in the first place.

One of my favorite ways to interact with puzzles is if they require spatial awareness. The goal of each level in Hook is to untangle the mess of connections you see before you. But since it’s a plain 2D affair, it’s more reminiscent of electrical circuit diagrams than anything else. And it also works quite the same way. You have the equivalent of logic gates available to you in order to steer the “electricity” from your button to the appropriate elements. And since all the elements are interlocked in some way, shape or form, you have to keep track which piece has to be removed next. One wrong move, one incorrect decision means that you’ll be trying to remove more than just that one hook you had it out for and send you frantically going over all of your connections again.

Don’t be fooled by the deceptively simple design of the title, it does have quite a few hard puzzles to solve. Unfortunately, to get to them, you’ll be treated to around 30 to 40 levels of mostly very simple puzzles and tutorials that you’ll breeze through without much stopping you. But the final 10 levels – and yes, the game contains a total of 50 levels – can test your patience quite a bit and require a lot of preparatory work, before you even touch one single logic gate.

It’s also unfortunate that the game is completely devoid of an options menu. There isn’t much to complain about the performance that would require an extensive selection of settings, but basic features like resolution and sound options would’ve been much appreciated.

If the price were any higher than what the developers are currently asking for – which, for the record, is $1 – I’d probably have more qualms over recommending this short little title, but as it stands, you could spend that amount on a lot of worse entertainment that doesn’t tickle your brain to the extent Hook does. So yeah, I’m willing to give this short little game a recommendation, because it’s flawlessly executed, elegant and simple in design, visually and aurally pleasing and doesn’t require a big investment for the privilege. The only real downside is that I would’ve liked some more levels. But in the end, isn’t that really a compliment if you want more of the same out of a title?

This game is a pretty chill puzzler, and a very fun way to zen out for 30-45 minutes. At higher levels the original puzzles are tricky without being super difficult, and the minimalist style and subtle music really helps one to zone out for a bit. I definitely recommend playing this game when you have to take your mind off stressful things for a while, it gives you something else to focus on in a relaxing, mellow way. After you complete a few puzzles, new tricks are added in a thoughtful way that teaches you problem-solving and increases the difficulty. However, once you really get into the game it ends after 50 (quick) puzzles. It would be a great addition to have more puzzles, continuing to increase in difficulty and complexity beyond the initial 50.

All in all, get this game. It'll grab you.

If you like rods then this game has you covered! As the game itself is so eager to stress, Hook is a short puzzler based on a web game prototype remade for Steam with 50 original, format-specific challenges. Looking not too dissimilar to a monochromatic circuit diagram, a series of sexy, sexy rods are laid out across the screen, connected by not so sexy pathways to thoroughly unappealing buttons. When these buttons are fiddled with, they retract the rods and remove them from play, taking the button and pathway with it. Remove them all to pass to the next challenge.

The catch is that some rods cross through one another, or have sweet curves surrounding the tips of other rods. If a button is pressed for a rod that isn't clear of all other rods then they bang hard against each other and force you to restart the puzzle (though, later, more difficult ones allow you three bangs before you're out). Remove them in the right order to gradually free them all up and reach the white screen climax.

Along the way they make it harder for you by adding things like buttons that deshaft multiple rods simultaneously, or pathways that can be altered, or having buttons and rods that aren't directly touching each other but are instead activated over distance remotely. But as complicated as this all sounds, in practice it's a relatively straightforward task to work out which order to tackle everything, or in a worse case scenario, it's pretty simple to figure everything out through a process of elimination as you push on these mysterious little buttons and try to understand just what the hell they do.

It's a fairly basic game that tickles your mind a little without taxing it too much, and in the hour it took for me to complete, I had fun at every point without ever feeling stressed out or frustrated, as can sometimes be the case with other puzzle games. It's short and minimal, but that's reflected in the low price that makes it an easy proposition to take a chance on. Hopefully this is just the start and more challenges are planned, as I'd gladly invest in future puzzle packs if they were released periodically for the same price until I either ran out of money or stopped being so interested in rods, that's how much I enjoyed this. I guess you could say I'm, ahem... hooked!... Please don't ever tell anyone I said that, this is just between you and me, OK? Cool.

If one hook hits another in the process of trying to retract, you fail. You have very limited ability to rework the wires, so the puzzle is in working out how to set up the wires so that you can retract the hooks in the correct sequence.

Hook never gets especially deep, though, so it's probably for the best that the game ends while it still feels relatively fresh. Short Review
A fairly short, minimalistic but thoroughly enjoyable puzzle game

Long Review
There is no tutorial to help you out; it really is simply a matter of sitting down, clicking on the circles and figuring out how they work but the basic game play is very simple and easy to work out

Effectively the point of the game is to remove objects in the correct order; the order being determined so when removed they do not move another object. You remove an object by clicking on a black circle which is connected via a matrix to each object. You are able to affect which parts of the matrix are connected so its important to make sure you are connected to the next object(s) that needs to be removed but not connected to the objects which should not (i.e. will be hooked as you try to remove them)

There are a total of 50 levels and it took me around an hour to complete them all.

There are no time or other pressures. The only restriction is that you can only make 3 mistakes before you are forced to replay the current puzzle from the beginning. Although I made the odd mistake I never had to restart a level.

I doubt whether there is any replay value in the game as there is only a single achievement for completing the game

I don’t consider myself a particularly smart person. Which is obviously why I greatly enjoy puzzle games, because they fill me with a sense of intelligence after overcoming certain particularly difficult puzzles. It sort of gives me the feeling that I’m smarter than whoever came up with these challenges in the first place. And I know that this is a very inaccurate representation of people who make puzzle games, because I realize that coming up with these difficult brainteasers in the first place requires an intellect far greater than mine in the first place.

One of my favorite ways to interact with puzzles is if they require spatial awareness. The goal of each level in Hook is to untangle the mess of connections you see before you. But since it’s a plain 2D affair, it’s more reminiscent of electrical circuit diagrams than anything else. And it also works quite the same way. You have the equivalent of logic gates available to you in order to steer the “electricity” from your button to the appropriate elements. And since all the elements are interlocked in some way, shape or form, you have to keep track which piece has to be removed next. One wrong move, one incorrect decision means that you’ll be trying to remove more than just that one hook you had it out for and send you frantically going over all of your connections again.

Don’t be fooled by the deceptively simple design of the title, it does have quite a few hard puzzles to solve. Unfortunately, to get to them, you’ll be treated to around 30 to 40 levels of mostly very simple puzzles and tutorials that you’ll breeze through without much stopping you. But the final 10 levels – and yes, the game contains a total of 50 levels – can test your patience quite a bit and require a lot of preparatory work, before you even touch one single logic gate.

It’s also unfortunate that the game is completely devoid of an options menu. There isn’t much to complain about the performance that would require an extensive selection of settings, but basic features like resolution and sound options would’ve been much appreciated.

If the price were any higher than what the developers are currently asking for – which, for the record, is $1 – I’d probably have more qualms over recommending this short little title, but as it stands, you could spend that amount on a lot of worse entertainment that doesn’t tickle your brain to the extent Hook does. So yeah, I’m willing to give this short little game a recommendation, because it’s flawlessly executed, elegant and simple in design, visually and aurally pleasing and doesn’t require a big investment for the privilege. The only real downside is that I would’ve liked some more levels. But in the end, isn’t that really a compliment if you want more of the same out of a title?
